OK.  So we can tweak them to swim faster, using their own energy.  If they can't find prey fast enough this will just kill them.  The main reason jellies are so successful IS their low energy use!  They can use currents to drift instead of using their own energy to move when prey is scarce, conserving their energy.  Souping them up defeats their basic survival strategy!  It's neat, but SO far from being useful.  And then there's the whole "jellies are a significant prey animal themselves" problem...and bioaccumulation makes that worse.

Just put a big metal spike in 'em. At turtle might eat one... once. But in all seriousness, I can't help but feel that this would be useless. The data they provide is all data that can be pretty effectively provided through use of buoys and other devices. Power requirements will increase drastically with the introduction of transmitters, as will response time with distance. Assuming they control the jellies, where will they send them and, after they arrive, will they be able to feed themselves without throwing off data? Will they be able to feed themselves at all? It just feels like an exercise in "can we" rather than a "do we need to" and when it comes to things like climate monitoring there are much better places that money could go to.

Imagine the following logical extreme from this jellybot example. Combine John with an electronic prosthetic to create...something awful and something out of a dystopian novel, a biohybrid robot, a hu-bot if you will. John becomes John-bot, cyborgized so that he can perform idealized, specialized tasks that scientists want him/it to perform. Who knows what electrical impulses could make this John (Jelly-John) do. Sounds like the Orwellian ethos gone even more over the edge amuck. Don't think ethicists should stay silent here. Are some scientists mad as in insane? Just wondering. Just 'cause the tech to be able to do something exists, even if same has some perceived positive benefits like oceanic exploration, doesn't mean that people should go ahead and do it. Giving what becomes Jelly-John this kind of elecpros [Newspeak for electronic prosthetic] makes him/it into being subjected to the Imperius Curse, one of the 3 Unforgivable Curses from Harry Potter, though in Muggle style thru technology: scientists would be in control of Jelly-John's nature & will, not John. Unforgivable indeed. Those who implement/execute the Imperius Curse are unforgiven. And who will speak on behalf of the jellyfish begins the process to help John, so that he never even has to contemplate becoming Jelly-John.
